comments.body:
After wrestling a bit with the balance definitions I proposed earlier, I think it makes sense to define three kinds of balance:
1. overall stateful tasks per _thread_ (including both active and standby)
2. overall active task per _thread_ (including both stateful active and stateless)
3. task-parallelism (so that the number of partitions of the same task is as distributed as possible over the _instances_)

We can generally require both stateful and active task balance, but task parallelism may get sacrificed in favor of the other two at times. It's beyond the scope of this assignor to try and optimize these tradeoffs, so we just don't worry too much about task-parallel balance when it's overconstrained.
I added a few matchers so that we can get more informative errors when our assertions fail.
Q: Why do we need this additional check?

L131-158 is just gathering the information about whether each task is correctly assigned or not, based on its type and the standby configs (and maybe the warmup config). It doesn't make any assertions. So this check is actually the assertion, that no tasks are incorrectly assigned.

Doing it this way is nicer, since when it fails, it tells you _all_ the incorrectly assigned tasks, not just the first one.
Similar to the other matchers, it just gives us mildly nicer test output.
